title: FirstFT: Today's top stories
text:
Joe Biden is facing mounting pressure from corporate America to avoid tax increases to fund the multitrillion-dollar infrastructure investments the US president has promised in the coming months.

The stand-off between the White House and US business is emerging as a new political hurdle for Biden's economic agenda, even as he moves closer to clinching congressional approval for an immediate $1.9tn fiscal stimulus plan, likely by mid-March.

The Biden administration and business groups largely agree on the need for additional large-scale government funding to modernise US infrastructure, finance research and development and promote green energy.

But the most influential lobby groups representing corporate America in Washington are warning the president against increasing their taxes to pay for the measures. They argue that including the tax hikes in a bill later this year would be economically harmful and could torpedo the legislation.

In addition to higher corporate taxes, Biden has proposed increasing capital gains taxes on individuals earning more than $1m and higher payroll taxes for high income households.

Coronavirus digest

  • India has stepped up efforts to curb the spread as case numbers top 11m.

  • BioNTech/Pfizer Covid-19 vaccine has been highly effective at preventing infection in Israel, according to the first real-world data showing that vaccination stops transmission of the virus.

  • Australia began its BioNTech/Pfizer Covid-19 vaccinations ahead of schedule on Sunday with Prime Minister Scott Morrison among the first to receive a shot. New Zealand also began vaccinating border control workers at the weekend.

  • US Covid-19 hospitalisations fell for a 40th consecutive day as the number of new cases and fatalities also declined. Racial inequality has plagued the country's vaccine rollout, with people living in areas hit hardest by virus being inoculated at a slower rate, according to FT analysis.

Tim Harford asks can we afford to pay for catch-up tuition for children learning remotely during the pandemic? Keep up to date with our coronavirus live blog.

In the news

HSBC intensifies its “pivot to Asia” The bank is moving top executives from London to Hong Kong, scrapping its US retail banking operation and planning further expansion in Singapore. The moves come as tensions rise between the west and China that have left the Hong Kong-founded, UK-headquartered bank in a precarious position. (FT)

Boeing 777 aircraft grounded Dozens of Boeing 777 aircraft have been grounded in the US and Japan after an engine failure that caused debris to be strewn across a Denver suburb. On Sunday the US ordered inspections of the Boeing 777 planes with Pratt & Whitney PW4000 engines after the incident that resulted in an emergency landing of a United Airlines flight the day before. (FT)

China urges Biden to lift sanctions China's foreign minister Wang Yi has urged Washington to lift sanctions and to stop interfering in the country's internal affairs and suppressing its tech sector, in his first big speech on US-China relations since Joe Biden's inauguration. (FT)

Myanmar protesters defy threats of violence Throngs of protesters joined a general strike against Myanmar's military junta on Monday in what organisers said was the biggest day of defiance since the coup, brushing aside a growing threat of violence by the regime. Security forces shot dead two protesters and injured several others on Saturday. (FT)

Beijing tightens online lending rules China's banking regulator has tightened rules governing how online lending platforms fund their loans — requiring them to contribute 30 per cent of the funding for loans they offer in partnership with banks. Analysts say the move could hit the valuation of Jack Ma's Ant Group. (FT)

ECB set to disappoint climate campaigners The European Central Bank is likely to adopt a less aggressive approach to tackling climate change than many campaigners want. It will rely mostly on improved financial modelling and disclosure rather than green asset purchases, according to several top policymakers. (FT)

Chinese law to allow coast guard use of arms The US has expressed concern about a new law that authorises the Chinese coast guard to fire on foreign ships operating in disputed waters claimed by Beijing in the South China Sea and East China Sea. Separately, Taiwan has strengthened its national security team as part of a new push for improving stalled dialogue with China. (FT)

  • Addressing the Munich security conference on Friday, US president Joe Biden urged the US and Europe to “prepare together for long-term strategic competition with China”. (FT)

Saudi women can join military Women in Saudi Arabia can now be employed as soldiers, lance corporals, corporals, sergeants and staff sergeants, according to local news reports. It is the latest in a series of moves that have gradually opened up jobs to women in the country. (Bloomberg)

The days ahead

Putin-Lukashenko talks Russia's president Vladimir Putin will on Monday hold talks with his Belarusian counterpart Alexander Lukashenko, who has faced intense political pressure from the opposition since a contested election last year. There have been echoes of the Belarusian protests in Russia's Navalny protests. (FT)

UK lockdown exit plans Prime Minister Boris Johnson on Monday will announce the UK government's road map out of the current lockdown. On Sunday Matt Hancock, health secretary, said the UK government would not accelerate plans to ease lockdown despite indications that the coronavirus vaccination is working. (FT)

What else we're reading

Billionaires' Row developer raises cash after property slump Extell Development, the real estate group behind some of the supertall towers of Manhattan's Billionaires' Row, is raising more than $300m through the sale of a stake in its lesser-known properties, as it wrestles with a slump in the market for luxury apartments. (FT)

Nikkei 30,000 brings back memories of 1980s mania The historic resonance of 1990 is powerful and these are heights that have not once, in 30 years, felt remotely recoverable, writes Leo Lewis. But there are also signs retail investors are changing Japan's markets. (FT)

Silicon Beach, or just another warm tax haven? Covid-19, coupled with the fear of rising taxes and regulation on the coasts, has accelerated corporate migration to southern states, writes Rana Foroohar. But the “techxodus” must not become a race to the bottom, in which cities end up giving away far more than they receive in property breaks or job creation tax credits. (FT)

The rise of the US's anti-Asian racism In 2019 there was just one reported incident of an anti-Asian hate crime in New York City. Last year, there were 20, according to New York Police Department data. As crimes against Asians increase, Kathleen Hou reflects on breaking out of a culture of “swallowing the bitterness”. (The Cut)

Colombia weighs a new aerial war on drugs With drug production soaring, Bogotá wants to revive its crop-spraying programme. But in 2015 the International Agency for Research on Cancer found that glyphosate, which was sprayed from the planes, was “probably carcinogenic for humans”. (FT)

Why once successful countries like the UK get left behind Since the global financial crisis, UK productivity has been virtually stagnant, writes Martin Wolf. The decline in productivity growth is not unique to the UK, but the country's deterioration was the biggest out of all G7 leading high-income economies, and a lack of innovation could be the problem. (FT)

Toxic offices don't change when they go virtual Even though staff are working from home, indefensible behaviour never stops, writes Pilita Clark. A new book by British business psychologist Clive Lewis also points out that such toxic behaviour is not just inhumane, it is costly to businesses. (FT)

Video of the day

How moving your money could help save the planet The money in our bank accounts, savings, investments and pensions is fuelling climate destruction. FT deputy news editor Alice Ross questions whether changing providers can safeguard returns while protecting the environment.
